Description: Egyptian sculpture carved from black granite; statue representing a striding Ptolemaic queen as Isis-Hathor in a hybrid Greek-Egyptian style;. Both arms along her body; holding a lotus flower in her left hand; with uraeus on forehead; socket for missing Isis-Hathor headdress on the top of head; eyes (originally inlaid) also missing; wearing a dress treated slightly in a Greek way ("wet drapery"), with Isis knot between breasts; the fine knotted garnment reveals partially her naked body below the folds of the dress; her back is against a back pillar in the unusual shape of an obelisk; broken below knees.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Published by Edgar, who dates this to the 1st century BC (Cairo CG27494). Statues of striding queens, with uraeus . A common representation of Ptolemaic queens with various parallels in basalt, marble, limestone or diorite with a back pillar (Bothmer et al. 1960, nos 113, see also 105, 123, 130, dated 240/200-80/50 BC; Walke and Higgs 2001 no.164). Bothmer, B. V., de Meulenaere, H. and Müller, H. W. 1960. Egyptian sculpture of the late period, 700 B.C. to A.D. 100. New York: Brooklyn Museum. Walker, S. and Higgs, P. (eds). 2001. Cleopatra of Egypt : from history to myth. London : British Museum.

The queen is dressed as the goddess Isis, as often is the case for Ptolemaic queens (Witt 1997; for a finer and earlier example: Goddio 2008, 294, no. 18). Goddio, F. (ed.) 2008. Egypt's Sunken Treasures, 2nd edn. Munich. Witt, R.E. 1997. Isis in the Ancient world, 2nd edn. Baltimore.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CA.17) (Phase 3)
